abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Punjab Irrigation Sector
            Development Policy Loan Project for Pakistan were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: focus on instruments and incentives for
            reforms rather than simply on organizations, programs and
            projects. Based on the past experience, both Government of
            Punjab and the Bank agreed that new approaches and
            instruments will be needed to meet the diverse set of
            challenges facing the water sector. The past investments in
            irrigation system rehabilitation no doubt brought benefits
            of reduced incidences of canal breaches and resolved
            siltation and erosion problems. However, without
            institutional changes and adequate Operation and Maintenance
            (O&M), the system reverted to pre-rehabilitation
            situation. Strong political championship, government
            ownership, and commitment are essential for the success and
            continuity of reform programs. The bank's support to
            Punjab's Irrigation Sector Reforms Program (ISRP) was
            designed on the basis of extensive analytical work
            undertaken by the federal and provincial governments as well
            as by the bank.
